stem: An 8-month-old infant is admitted with a 3-day history of runny nose, cough, and decreased feeding. Today, the infant is tachypneic (RR 64) with intercostal retractions and clear nasal drainage. Complete the bowtie to guide management.

actions.text: Provide humidified oxygen and monitor SpO2
Frequent nasal suctioning with a bulb syringe

parameters.text: Respiratory rate and effort (work of breathing)

rationale.correct: RSV causes inflammation and mucus in the bronchioles. Infants are 'obligate nose breathers,' so clearing secretions (suctioning) and supporting oxygenation are priorities. Monitoring hydration is key as tachypnea and mucus make feeding difficult.
rationale.incorrect: RSV is viral; antibiotics won't help. CPT is not routinely used for bronchiolitis and can be stressful for the infant. While skin color is important, work of breathing and hydration are more sensitive monitoring points for RSV progression.
clinicalPearls: Implement Contact and Droplet precautions for RSV.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the RR > 60, the infant is at high risk for aspiration; NPO or IV fluids may be needed.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for RSV / Bronchiolitis
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Frequent nasal suctioning with a bulb syringe; Provide humidified oxygen and monitor SpO2. Monitor: Respiratory rate and effort (work of breathing); Hydration status and I&Os. RSV is viral; antibiotics won't help. CPT is not routinely used for bronchiolitis and can be stressful for the infant. While skin color is important, work of breathing and hydration are more sensitive monitoring points for RSV progression.
